texts.shortText: Armina sp.7 NSSI, Armina sp.6 NSSI2, Armina sp. GZ, FGMA and Two Oceans, Pierre's armina, Striped sand slug.

A large, black cladobranch with alternating broad and narrow cream to yellow stripes. The head has a black oral veil with a frilled yellow margin. The rhinophores are black, have pale to peach-coloured tips, and a white to pale blue patch between them. The stripes on the notum may merge or split. The notum has a yellow margin The gills are located between the mantle and the foot. The foot is peach-coloured with a yellow margin.

Global: South Africa, Mozambique, western Pacific.

Local/Regional: False Bay, 2 â€“ 30m in depth.

This species is usually found on sand or in seagrass fields. It has a very broad distribution, possibly because of the broad distribution of its prey species, but its occasional presence in False Bay may simply be due to warm water pulse events.
The species feeds on the Radial sea pen, Actinoptylum molle.
This species is hermaphroditic. Egg ribbon colour and shape not yet known.

This species can be confused with several warm-water species of Armina, but so far it is the only warm-water Armina to have been observed in False Bay. It is distinguished from other tropical species by the head patch immediately behind and between the rhinophores.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 214).

Gosliner, T, Jones, G, Beasley, L, Claassens, L, Fraser, V, Herbert, D... et al. (2023). Southern African Sea Slugs. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 430).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 146).

Zsilavecz, G (2007). Nudibranchs of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. Southern Underwater Research Group, Cape Town (p. 76).
